author: Special Correspondent
text:
A two-day cultural programme, ‘Svanubhava’, organised by artiste T.M. Krishna and Saraswathi Vidyalayam in BHEL will commence on February 25.

The cultural movement on Indian performing arts will provide an opportunity to students to exhibit their talents.

It aims at bringing together students from various educational institutions and students of the performing arts to celebrate and learn from leading artistes throughout the country, according to a press note from Mr. Krishna.

The earlier events of ‘Svanubhava’ had been organised in Chennai, New Delhi, Tiruchi, Jaffna, and Bengaluru.

Nearly 2,000 students will attend and benefit through the programme, he said. Events on folk music, dance, classical music, and classical dance would form part of the programme.

An interactive session would be held at the end of each programme to inspire the young. “We will invite students from schools and colleges in and around the city,” he said.

The focus of the programme would be on creating community of students of performing arts and instil in them a sense of confidence on nursing and developing their talents.

It would provide for students every opportunity to interact with one another and with leading artistes.

It would prompt students to respect and develop an understanding and appreciating various forms of arts. “Our vision is to create teams of students of various performing arts in a cluster of cities across the country and build sustainable communities,” he added.

Programmes on Villupattu by Subbu Arumugam, flute recital by Chandankumar, puppetry show by K. Kesavasamy and nagaswaram concert by Sheik Mehboob Shubhani will form part of the event.
title: Svanubhava programme from February 25
